document.title: History and Social Science Standards of Learning for Virginia Public Schools

7A07FB020CC3415780C2471DA7A0CB06.description:
explaining scientific and technological changes and evaluating their impact on American
culture, including media.

655B9D21241E4B30A490C73FA35C1EA5.description: connecting the legacy of the Civil Rights Movement to the election of Barack Obama; and

3F96CFE61CB7427DACA656528AA26E63.description:
explaining social movements, including but not limited to the Vietnam War and the rise of
the anti-war movement, Woodstock, the rise of the conservative movement and the election
of Ronald Reagan, Women's Movement, Gay Rights Movement, Pro-life Movement, and
an increased domestic focus on HIV/AIDS, the rise of antisemitism and hate crimes, and
domestic terrorism;

0189FE8774814450B251A468CD69F702.description:
analyzing key events and conditions that have given rise to terrorism as an attack on
democracy and the United States' role in defending democracy, including, but not limited to
the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center, the 2000 bombing of the USS Cole, attacks
on U.S. Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, and the 9/11 attacks on the United States in
2001;

6BA555C14430471F81E632FE3A6BD859.description:
assessing the development of and changes in domestic policies due to Supreme Court
decisions and acts of Congress, including, but not limited to Brown v. Board of Education,
the Federal Highway Act of 1956, the American Indian Movement (AIM), the Indian SelfDetermination and Education Assistance Act, the Equal Pay Act, the Americans with
Disabilities Act, Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, the Marriage Equality
Act, Obergefell v. Hodges, Gideon v. Wainwright, Miranda v. Arizona, and Roe v. Wade
leading to Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization;

DA3F3C1FCCAB41649466E5EFAB8D6DF4.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to analyze political and social conditions
in the United States during the second half of the 20th century and early 21st century by

F3FE968FB7E647419BAF710F54C7671F.description: analyzing the effect of the Black Power Movement.

EDDBE04311B9431A9E6E03A39770AB88.description:
explaining how the tenets of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored
People (NAACP), the 1963 March on Washington, the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and
the Voting Rights Act of 1965 had an effect on all Americans; and

E3E7982B5C6F4DD2B95AC0966AFBDABB.description:
analyzing key events, including, but not limited to the murder of Emmett Till, bus
boycotts, Little Rock Central High School desegregation, Greensboro sit-ins, Freedom
Rides, Birmingham demonstrations, the 1963 March on Washington, the Freedom
Summer, and Selma to Montgomery Marches, with additional emphasis on events in
Virginia;

915F55703772424387759CB3513048CF.description:
analyzing the origins of the Civil Rights Movement, the effects of segregation, and
efforts to desegregate schools, transportation, and public areas;

4D5F03C77BE7476EB0E89CBCCC23FAB0.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to analyze the causes and effects of the
Civil Rights Movement by

CBFD9243B4134E05AA8A6704077E9FAC.description:
explaining how American foreign policy pressure, economic power and defense policy,
and the assertion of American values led to the end of the Cold War.

575E560E7D184650998D27E7F855F8F4.description:
analyzing the changing role of the United States in Asia, including Korea, Vietnam, and
China, and the experiences of refugees from those nations; and

DA0F44ADDEC84C319AD75C6D511BB653.description:
describing events and leaders of the Cold War, including the Bay of Pigs, the Cuban
Missile Crisis, John F. Kennedy, and Nikita Khrushchev;

E3B1ACD15C834ED3B0303CB49E0C504E.description:
explaining the long-term impact of the Marshall Plan, the formation of NATO, the
Warsaw Pact, and the efforts of the United States to protect Western Europe;

0B9FC509F2654A258DBBB46889AA4F24.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to analyze the United States’
foreign policy during the Cold War era by

304EB6D89D91455A81B56A523CA6FF07.description: The United States since World War II

CFEDCBED8CDA41D69BAA9125FE295042.description:
describing the significance of America’s role in the Allied victory, the Marshall Plan, and
the significance of the United Nations.

CF8040EA8CE64FA7A75247B208377364.description:
analyzing the Holocaust, beginning with the history and role of antisemitism in the
persecution of Jews, the persecutions of other targeted groups, challenges related to the
immigration of Jews, Hitler’s “Final Solution,” liberation, post-war trials, post-war
immigration to the United States, and the creation of the modern state of Israel;

CBCC1A7F85594A248F048D1631E4B229.description:
describing major battles of World War II, including Midway, Normandy, Iwo Jima,
Okinawa, and the Battle of the Bulge, as well as battles in Holland, Italy, and North Africa;

9FFE372BEAAE4BA085A66E2B7C70E38B.description:
identifying the similarities and differences in the strategy, major battles, and impacts of key
leaders of the Axis and Allied Powers;

57CDAFCF493B4B44B326349D4CF25209.description:
comparing and contrasting totalitarianism in Imperial Japan, communist Soviet Union,
fascist Italy, and Nazi Germany;

37785CA9557F4ABFA14D701741756E0A.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to analyze the United States’
involvement in World War II by

403D15F3615E40168889E207770FCD22.description:
evaluating and explaining how Franklin D. Roosevelt’s New Deal measures addressed
the Great Depression and expanded the government’s role in the economy, its features,
and effects.

58A0965F9F0B422DB9BED2ABB3886997.description:
explaining the causes of the Great Depression, including, but not limited to bank failures, stock purchases on margins, credit, overproduction, high tariffs and
protectionism, and the 1929 stock market crash; and

968804E14E2445CEA75FE001B3B7538D.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to describe the effects of the
Great Depression and New Deal policies on the United States by

62740EB32AAA43E3861780A90A1F4FF6.description:
examining the Great Migration and its influence on the Harlem Renaissance,
prompting new trends in literature, music, and art, and the work of writers,
including, but not limited to Zora Neale Hurston and Langston Hughes.

0AE8A87DB9E24C32B8EA7ABBFEB519B3.description:
examining the changing role of women in society and in the passage of the
Eighteenth Amendment and the Nineteenth Amendment to the Constitution of the
United States; and

F74833C4BB0E40FEA18541EE4B4C225B.description:
analyzing the effects of changes in immigration to the United States including, but
not limited to the Immigration Act of 1918 and the Immigration Act of 1924;

F059C84BC4554949899AF40AC0F15A4C.description:
analyzing the connections between the Bolshevik Revolution and the First Red
Scare, anarchist bombings, and the Palmer Raids;

6BDE2132FF7F405FBC1C235AE5DECE89.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to understand key international
and domestic events, interests, and philosophies of the 1920s and 1930s by

F151A3FF38714B09A3C78020AF219A42.description:
evaluating and explaining the terms of the Treaty of Versailles, including, but not
limited to the national debate in response to the formation of the League of Nations.

20B9027A93D045BCBBAE96F4649F9982.description:
evaluating the events, leaders, and changes that brought America out of a period of
isolationism to enter WWI;

86EA9AE19D6346C585F6497F5C94BDBC.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to analyze the emerging role of the
United States in world affairs during the end of the 19th and early 20th centuries by

4FE8A08AF06549DBA612614B6FFD2CCE.description:
explaining the emergence of public colleges, HBCUs, and land-grant institutions in
Virginia and the United States as a way to expand educational opportunities and
build specific skills and knowledge in agricultural and technological advances.

6FC27F39186641B1874FC3FCF4CECE6B.description:
analyzing the effects of prejudice, discrimination, and “Jim Crow” laws including,
but not limited to the responses of Booker T. Washington and W.E.B. DuBois,
lynching and racial terror, race riots, the suppression of voting rights in Virginia and
other Southern states, Ida B. Wells-Barnett’s anti-lynching crusade, the practice of
eugenics, and the U.S. Supreme Court 1927 Buck v. Bell decision; and

1D355C811B084A4EA17707BB1F2955D3.description:
examining the “Byrd machine” and its dominance in Virginia government in the first
half of the 20th century;

B4BB8000CD224B9AB39A3117246C54F9.description:
analyzing the transformation of the American economy from agrarian to industrial,
the growth of cities and trade, the role of the railroads and communication systems,
and the concentration of wealth and mass production that created goods at cheaper
and faster rates, including, but not limited to industrial leaders such as Andrew
Carnegie, Andrew Mellon, and John D. Rockefeller and the growth of American
philanthropy;

99207744B8F54A4C88D981A1936C6B83.description:
examining and evaluating the motivations, contributions, and challenges immigrants
to the United States faced before, during, and upon arrival;

EAE0E0A8C2A448A59DA8220EF5B68DFD.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to analyze how the nation grew and
 changed from the end of Reconstruction through the early 20th century b

DF2903300A6646B4AF2E4514DC6449E5.description: Industrialization, Emergence of Modern America, and World Conflicts

E7925409B01F48BCB81491F6F6EB44D7.description:
evaluating the role of the biracial Readjuster Party in Virginia during Reconstruction in
providing funds to expand a system of public schools and expanding employment
opportunities for African Americans.

C2D33CF1CB6E40CA9CE9722AF3623CEA.description:
evaluating Virginia’s stance on the Fourteenth Amendment, Virginia’s 1870
Constitution, and readmittance to Congress; and

B48C6CBF1D214857BE2176D87B63786B.description:
evaluating and explaining the political and economic impact of the war and
Reconstruction, including the adoption of the Thirteenth, Fourteenth, and Fifteenth
Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, sharecropping, the Freedman’s
Bureau, and the rise of white supremacist groups;

433645934F1647CDBF926E4BDB15F378.description: evaluating postwar Reconstruction plans presented by key leaders of the Civil War;

EEB1B72A0CD143F889B82D3E5E405498.description:
evaluating and explaining the impact of the war on Americans, with emphasis on
Virginians, enslaved and free Blacks, the common soldier, and the home front;

095673D0287B4884A791C165BD087090.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to analyze the major turning
points of the Civil War and Reconstruction eras by

4AABFB19643649EA9B763AC59BE3D3E1.description:
explaining the extension of rights provided in the Thirteenth, Fourteenth, and Fifteenth
Amendments to the Constitution of the United States.

980177F71D1744ECBF3E26B6B371B56D.description:
analyzing key policies and actions, including, but not limited to the Missouri Compromise,
the Compromise of 1850, the Kansas-Nebraska Act, Dred Scott v. Sanford, and the
Emancipation Proclamation; and

B044DCA3AC4E4522B27F973017D8B2BE.description: describing the impacts of abolitionists, including, but not limited to Sojourner Truth, William Lloyd Garrison, Frederick Douglass, and Harriet Beecher Stowe;

A05C12375C1F45AAACBF94552B1643E6.description: explaining how slavery is the antithesis of freedom;

533CF33AEAE647DCA3004BFC7D9869CB.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to analyze the development and
abolition of slavery in the United States by

AD392E69387F4F8291273396B46FA42A.description:
evaluating the cultural, economic, and political issues that divided the nation,
including the role of slavery, the abolitionist movements, and tariffs, in the conflicts
that led to the Civil War.

A6E767E5AFFC4ED5B4D7339A593EE698.description: examining the Texas Revolution and the Mexican-American War; and

0F33E465F7BB423E81CE4E1DDB18C424.description:
analyzing the social and cultural changes during the period, including, but not
limited to immigration and “The Age of the Common Man” (Jacksonian Era);

DBEF9EEB7D84480DBB606F388136BF3B.description:
describing the political results of territorial expansion and its impact on Indigenous
peoples;

E26F32C6860341ECA5A32B1FC4164F0D.description:
assessing the political and economic changes that occurred during this period, with
emphasis on James Madison and the War of 1812;

022C0E42D84F4FBD86EC8BF0661392C3.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to analyze major events in
Virginia and United States history during the first half of the 19th century by

A47A2216663A43ADBB9E3108028AC7DD.description:
explaining the significance of Chief Justice John Marshall and the Marbury v. Madison
decision.

A62F757E2B2F40A78645CA1B932B8B9C.description:
analyzing the issues and debates over the role of the federal government and the
formation of political parties during the early National Era; and

AD8F642E08584C668EB5AEB3E7E14B2B.description:
comparing the powers granted through the Constitution to citizens, Congress, the
president, and the Supreme Court with those reserved to the states;

EFE955F52B414DA2819C2690FE7E33C4.description:
describing the major compromises necessary to produce the Constitution of the United
States, with emphasis on the struggles of ratification, the reasons for the Bill of Rights,
and the roles of James Madison, Alexander Hamilton, George Mason, John Adams, and
George Washington;

DEC7E639EFC74886A782968576CF6C82.description: identifying the strengths and weaknesses of the Articles of Confederation;

EFD2EC61A44142EFB8FB05E7EC0382BD.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to describe the development and
significance of the American political system by

1BBF04146FD5467B9FEBE96F06BE5802.description: analyzing the U.S. Presidents of this era, with emphasis on the presidents from Virginia.

70D40672895E4199838984F574159E1A.description:
evaluating how key principles in the Declaration of Independence grew in importance to
become unifying ideas of American political philosophy; and

350D67B86E1D4C4A842469CD42D7A40E.description:
analyzing the intervention of France and other factors that led to colonial victory in the
Revolutionary War;

03C5702902D34F5D94C3D7D86E1DAA56.description:
examining the contributions of those involved in the drafting and signing of the
Declaration of Independence and the lasting legacy of the document;

33A81592E00A4EFE81AC65557C06592D.description:
describing how political, religious, and economic ideas and interests contributed to the start
of the American Revolution, including, but not limited to the resistance to imperial policy,
the Stamp Act, the Townsend Acts, taxes on tea, the Coercive Acts, the Boston Tea Party,
the Boston Massacre, Patrick Henry’s “Give Me Liberty, or Give Me Death” speech, the
Battles of Lexington and Concord, the Battle of Bunker Hill, the Second Continental
Congress and the Olive Branch Petition, and Thomas Paine’s Common Sense;

1C1B53A6DED64B869DA12A72CE6E7EBC.description: describing the results of the French and Indian War;

9C7DF7D70EB846F188ACDB1EBA5682DE.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to understand the issues and events
leading to and during the revolutionary period by

9C07F0F302E14785ACAC0693B28A8BD2.description:
describing the violent conflicts among the Indigenous peoples’ nations, including the
competing claims for control of lands.

51768EB60099407C8884D8A40BB03215.description: explaining the conflicts before the Revolutionary War; and

57A0B3FB89EB473CAFC16774419868BD.description: describing the significance of Bacon’s Rebellion;

832638F55CFB410ABDD018F816700180.description:
describing the competition among the English, French, Spanish, Dutch, and Indigenous
peoples for control of North America;

676CBD7A6ACC4EB1ABEA08F21B72DABD.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to analyze the cooperation and conflict
between the Indigenous peoples and the new settlers by

B496B7655D644AEEB0FEAD2E51CBFC6D.description:
examining the cultures of enslaved Africans and identifying the various ways they persisted
towards freedom.

3C2AC2C75DD943DD9881D987FABAFC52.description:
analyzing the growth of the colonial economy that maximized profits through the use of
indentured servitude and race-based enslavement of Africans; and

CB33791C7A0F428FA374FD5C89D17A18.description: describing the slave trade in the U.S., Virginia, and Richmond;

9F4700D6865747A3982ABCC19905EB66.description:
describing the Middle Passage, the Transatlantic Slave Trade, chattel slavery, indentured
servitude, and forced labor;

5B764FAE63FD4458AE94DFFE46C8C9F3.description:
describing the diverse cultures, languages, skills, and perspectives of Africans who were
captured there and enslaved in the Americas;

5965C38B7A2447EF9AA3107F97013B69.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to explain the development of African
American culture in America and the impact of the institution of slavery by

CE6F8B65F395459F8D3521EACFFDD0A1.description:
explaining the early democratic ideas and practices that emerged during the colonial period,
including the significance of representative assemblies and town councils.

5E6FCD4E4142426194FC39C2B208EB8A.description:
describing European settlement in the Americas, the Great Awakening, the character,
practices, and growth of religious toleration, and the free exercise of religion;

4A77D1277F7D4BA19B27320D78099905.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to describe the political, religious,
social, and economic characteristics of the first 13 colonies by

D048700172024BEC969304A23F8B8C62.description:
examining the trade routes, resources, and products that linked Africa, the West Indies, the
American colonies, and Europe.

F18DE02FFF3341B68F14403F608EAE13.description:
connecting the aims, obstacles, and accomplishments of the explorers and sponsors of key
expeditions to the Spanish Reconquista, the Protestant Reformation, and the CounterReformation; and

E3AA78864A454102BBF29D9BEDFA0DDE.description:
distinguishing how different Indigenous Peoples of North America used available resources
to develop their culture, language, skills, and perspectives, including, but not limited to the
nations in the Northeast, the Mississippi River Valley, the Atlantic seaboard, the Pacific
coast, and the Southwest of North America;

CD2874C8326B4A72AB1EB02BCD8B69E5.description: The student will apply history and social science skills to describe early North America by

A62D8A0E846C4F0B837A1D87716BDB7B.description: Early America Through the Founding of the New Nation

4C10DA2C6E8B4835ACEE561AA376697D.description:
contextualizing corroborating and evaluating sources for credibility, propaganda, and bias
to determine patterns and trends in Virginia and United States history.

507C031408CE40958A030B684C9C50EE.description:
developing products that reflect an understanding of research and content to make real-life
connections; and

3748789E23054E57B98DC47C02924F27.description: engaging and communicating as an informed individual with different perspectives;

00F492404C134444B2494551BF07A7CA.description:
using economic decision-making models to analyze and explain the incentives for and
consequences of a specific choice;

1E72411934E040889CAE15F82F5EBCD3.description: determining cause and effect to analyze connections;

CCED96FB44314967959A0BF7E7E2032A.description:
comparing and contrasting historical, cultural, economic, and political
perspectives;

3A227935019644DDB2A79141112C80B3.description:
investigating and analyzing evidence from multiple sources to construct arguments
and draw conclusions;

C3B3825FC73A4BA88830E135A0E972DA.description:
questioning and using inquiry to construct arguments, using evidence from
multiple sources;

2D2BE551EDBB4B869ECB9C672AAC1D15.description:
applying geographic skills to determine and/or predict patterns and trends of people, places,
and events;

F6EE1709C81F4EB9AC5CBA8066D56DBF.description: The student will apply history and social science skills to the content by
